userStories.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
userStories.tip: Eat whole linseed scattered over toast

userStories.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?

condition.description:
Constipation means that a person has three or fewer bowel movements in a week. The stool can be hard and dry. Sometimes it is painful to pass. At one time or another, almost everyone gets constipated. In most cases, it lasts a short time and is not serious.

There are many things you can do to prevent constipation. They include

  • Eating more fruits, vegetables and grains, which are high in fiber
  • Drinking plenty of water and other liquids
  • Getting enough exercise
  • Taking time to have a bowel movement when you need to
  • Using laxatives only if your doctor says you should
  • Asking your doctor if medicines you take may cause constipation

It's not important that you have a bowel movement every day. If your bowel habits change, however, check with your doctor.

NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
indications: constipation (laxative and stool softener) bowel evacuation
condition.name: Constipation

indications: Constipation (laxative and stool softener) Bowel evacuation

carousel_items: It's best to take daily doses at bedtime or you can take it twice a day, but not for more than one week. Works in about 12-72 hours.
Ask your doctor about giving Colace to anyone younger than 2 years.
Don't use if you're taking mineral oil for constipation. Ask your doctor first.
Ask your doctor before taking Colace if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Check with your baby doctor before using or if you're pregnant or breastfeeding.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Colace is a stool softener. It allows both fats and water into stool, which softens it and makes it easier to pass.
basics.bottom_line: Colace takes longer to work that some alternatives, but it's a more comfortable way to relieve constipation.
downsides: May take up to 12 to 72 hours to take effect.
People who are older have medical conditions and take a lot of medicines may need more than 200 mg a day to get results.
It may be weaker than alternatives since it isn't a laxative. Studies show that stool softeners like Colace may be less effective than psyllium when it comes to treating constipation.

downsides_processed.orig: May take up to 12 to 72 hours to take effect.
People who are older have medical conditions and take a lot of medicines may need more than 200 mg a day to get results.
It may be weaker than alternatives since it isn't a laxative. Studies show that stool softeners like Colace may be less effective than psyllium when it comes to treating constipation.

upsides: Colace is a gentle, non-irritating, non-stimulant constipation reliever.
It doesn't cause cramping or the uncomfortable feeling that you "have to go right now".
Most people feel Colace is worth the hassle.
It's safe to use short-term during pregnancy and if you're breast-feeding, but you should still check with your baby doctor first.
Colace is used to prevent straining in people who recently had a heart attack.
It's a good choice after surgery, giving birth, or when you have hemorrhoids.

drugs.name: Colace

carousel_items_processed.orig: It's best to take daily doses at bedtime or you can take it twice a day, but not for more than one week. Works in about 12-72 hours.
Ask your doctor about giving Colace to anyone younger than 2 years.
Don't use if you're taking mineral oil for constipation. Ask your doctor first.
Ask your doctor before taking Colace if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Check with your baby doctor before using or if you're pregnant or breastfeeding.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

risks_warnings.title: Laxative dependence
risks_warnings.description: Don't use Colace for more than 1 week. Constipation is common in people who are on certain medications, aren't able to be active or can't move well, or don't drink enough water or other fluids. Older people are less sensitive to being thirsty, so they drink less, can get dehydrated and constipated. It’s always best to use Colace short-term. Better long term solutions may be stool softeners, bulk-forming fiber therapy, and osmotic medicines.
risk_factors: People who can't walk or move well (immobility)

description_processed.orig: Don't use Colace for more than 1 week. Constipation is common in people who are on certain medications, aren't able to be active or can't move well, or don't drink enough water or other fluids. Older people are less sensitive to being thirsty, so they drink less, can get dehydrated and constipated. It’s always best to use Colace short-term. Better long term solutions may be stool softeners, bulk-forming fiber therapy, and osmotic medicines.

risks_warnings.title: Bowel blockage
risks_warnings.description: Stop taking Colace and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, pain or bulging in your belly that doesn't go away, have rectal bleeding, and no bowel movement after taking. These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.
risk_factors: Other condition that causes blockage or narrowing of bowel

description_processed.orig: Stop taking Colace and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, pain or bulging in your belly that doesn't go away, have rectal bleeding, and no bowel movement after taking. These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.

risks_warnings.title: Electrolyte imbalance
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Colace or taking it for too long can cause changes in your electrolytes. Electrolytes help your body function properly. Make sure you take Colace as directed on the product label or by your doctor or pharmacist.
risk_factors: Taking with medications that cause electrolyte imbalance

description_processed.orig: Taking too much Colace or taking it for too long can cause changes in your electrolytes. Electrolytes help your body function properly. Make sure you take Colace as directed on the product label or by your doctor or pharmacist.

carousel_items: Swallow tablets whole (don't chew or crush) at bedtime, but not for more than one week.
Tablet works in 6 to 12 hours. Suppository works in 15 minutes to an hour, so make sure you're near a bathroom.
Don't take tablets within 1 hour of taking antacids, milk or dairy products.
Be sure to remove the wrapper from the suppository before inserting it into your rectum.
Ask your doctor about giving Dulcolax to anyone younger than 6 years.
Don't take if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Check with your baby doctor before using or if you're breast-feeding.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Dulcolax is a stimulant laxative that you can take by mouth or in a suppository. It causes waves of contractions (peristalsis) in your intestine muscles to push stool through. It also makes stool more watery.
basics.bottom_line: Dulcolax works fast and the suppositories work even faster to relieve your constipation, as long as you're okay with it "cramping" your style a bit.
downsides: Dulcolax can cause cramping, stomach upset, feeling faint, and the feeling that you "have to go right now".
You have to be comfortable with putting the medicine in your rectum.
Suppositories can cause slight rectal burning.

downsides_processed.orig: Dulcolax can cause cramping, stomach upset, feeling faint, and the feeling that you "have to go right now".
You have to be comfortable with putting the medicine in your rectum.
Suppositories can cause slight rectal burning.

upsides: Most people said it was worth taking and it wasn't too much of a hassle.
Tablets give overnight relief of your constipation.
Dulcolax can also be used to treat constipation caused by spinal cord injury.
Suppositories give you quick relief without having to drink a large amount of liquid medicine.

upsides_processed.orig: Most people said it was worth taking and it wasn't too much of a hassle.
Tablets give overnight relief of your constipation.
Dulcolax can also be used to treat constipation caused by spinal cord injury.
Suppositories give you quick relief without having to drink a large amount of liquid medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Although only very low levels of Dulcolax were detected with daily dosing up to 7 days, the risk to your unborn baby can't be ruled out. Dulcolax isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor first.

carousel_items: It's important to take each dose with at least 8 ounces (a full glass) of water or other liquid. Works in about 12-72 hours.
Don't take more than 8 caplets in a 24 hour period without asking your doctor first and not for more than one week.
Don't take Fibercon within 2 hours before or after taking other medicines. It may interact and affect how they work.
If you take Fibercon then have chest pain, vomiting, trouble breathing or swallowing, get medical help immediately.
Ask your doctor before taking Fibercon if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Ask your doctor about giving Fibercon to anyone younger than 12 years.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Fibercon is a fiber-based laxative. It adds bulk and moisture to your intestine, which softens stool and makes it easier to pass.
basics.bottom_line: Fibercon is a natural fiber laxative that's safe enough to take during pregnancy. Just make sure you take it with plenty of liquid.
downsides: You may have to take Fibercon daily for 1-3 days to see full effects.
If you don't take it with enough liquid, it could swell and block your throat and cause choking.
Not the best choice for people who have swallowing problems or aren't able to drink lots of liquids.
Can cause heartburn, gas, and belly cramps.

downsides_processed.orig: You may have to take Fibercon daily for 1-3 days to see full effects.
If you don't take it with enough liquid, it could swell and block your throat and cause choking.
Not the best choice for people who have swallowing problems or aren't able to drink lots of liquids.
Can cause heartburn, gas, and belly cramps.

upsides: Some people felt Fibercon was a hassle but still worth it.
It's safe to use short-term during pregnancy and breast-feeding as long as you take it with plenty of liquid, but you should still check with your baby doctor first.
Less gas and bloating compared to psyllium laxative products.

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: Fibercon can affect how other medicines are absorbed in the body when you take them together. Make sure you take it 2 hours before or after other medicines and vitamins.

These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.

carousel_items: Magnesium Citrate starts working in 30 minutes to 6 hours.
Works fast, so don't take it too close to bedtime.
The dose is different for adults and children so check the label and ask your doctor about giving to anyone younger than 6 years.
It tastes better if you chill the bottle before you take it. Make sure you drink 8 ounces (a full glass) of water or other liquid after each dose.

Ask your doctor before taking Magnesium Citrate if you have kidney disease, are on a limited magnesium or sodium diet, have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Stop taking Magnesium Citrate and call your doctor if you have pain, swelling or bulging in your belly, rectal bleeding, or haven't had a bowel movement after taking.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.
For short-term use. Don't use it for more than one week.

basics.benefits_moa: Magnesium citrate is an osmotic and stimulant laxative. It uses osmosis to keep more water in your intestine, which softens your stool and makes it easier to pass. It also causes waves of contractions (peristalsis) in your intestine muscles to push stool through.
basics.bottom_line: Magnesium citrate works well if you need to really get things moving, but it's not a good medicine to manage chronic constipation.
downsides: It doesn't work for everyone and some people feel it's a hassle.
Some brands are of Magnesium Citrate are tinted red and can change the color of your stool.
Can cause dizziness, weakness, diarrhea, and the feeling that you "have to go right now".
Magnesium Citrate contains magnesium which prevents certain medicines from working properly. Make sure you take your dose of Magnesium Citrate at least 2 hours before or after other medicines.
You can't take it for more than a week or so.

downsides_processed.orig: It doesn't work for everyone and some people feel it's a hassle.
Some brands are of Magnesium Citrate are tinted red and can change the color of your stool.
Can cause dizziness, weakness, diarrhea, and the feeling that you "have to go right now".
Magnesium Citrate contains magnesium which prevents certain medicines from working properly. Make sure you take your dose of Magnesium Citrate at least 2 hours before or after other medicines.
You can't take it for more than a week or so.

upsides: Really strong laxative that gets things moving fast.
Can also be used to prep your bowel before you go for surgery or colonoscopy. Your doctor will give you specific instructions if you use it this way.

risks_warnings.title: Electrolyte imbalance
risks_warnings.description: Magnesium citrate can cause dizziness or lightheadedness; irregular heartbeat; muscle cramps; unusual tiredness or weakness; bloating; cramping; diarrhea; nausea; gas; increased thirst. Taking too much Magnesium citrate or taking it for too long can cause changes in your electrolytes. Electrolytes help your body function properly. Make sure you take Magnesium citrate as directed on the product label or by your doctor or pharmacist.
risk_factors: Taking with medications that cause electrolyte imbalance

Taking too much Magnesium citrate or taking it for too long can cause changes in your electrolytes. Electrolytes help your body function properly. Make sure you take Magnesium citrate as directed on the product label or by your doctor or pharmacist.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Although it appears to be low, the risk to your unborn baby can't be ruled out even with short-term use. Magnesium citrate isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor first.

description_processed.orig: Although it appears to be low, the risk to your unborn baby can't be ruled out even with short-term use. Magnesium citrate isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Worsening of neuromuscular conditions
risks_warnings.description: Can worsen muscle weakness conditions like myasthenia gravis or Lambert Eaton syndrome. Tell your doctor if you have these conditions so you can look at other medicine choices for your constipation.
risk_factors: Taking Magnesium citrate if you have kidney disease and neuromuscular disease
Taking Magnesium citrate if you have neuromuscular disease

description_processed.orig: Can worsen muscle weakness conditions like myasthenia gravis or Lambert Eaton syndrome. Tell your doctor if you have these conditions so you can look at other medicine choices for your constipation.

risks_warnings.title: High magnesium levels
risks_warnings.description: Magnesium can build up in your blood if you have kidney problems. High magnesium levels can be dangerous and affect your heart, cause weakness and lower your calcium levels. Don't take Magnesium citrate if you have problems with your kidneys or are taking other magnesium-containing medicines. or supplements..
risk_factors: Taking other magnesium-containing medicines or supplements

description_processed.orig: Magnesium can build up in your blood if you have kidney problems. High magnesium levels can be dangerous and affect your heart, cause weakness and lower your calcium levels. Don't take Magnesium citrate if you have problems with your kidneys or are taking other magnesium-containing medicines. or supplements..

carousel_items: Psyllium works in about 12-72 hours for constipation.
It's important to take each dose with at least 8 ounces (a full glass) of water or other liquid (not hot liquids).
Mix powder well and drink right away up to 3 times a day (build up to this slowly), but not for more than one week.
Don't take Psyllium within 2 hours before or after taking other medicines. It may interact and affect how they work.
If you take Psyllium then have chest pain, vomiting, trouble breathing or swallowing, get medical help immediately.
Ask your doctor before taking Psyllium if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Ask your doctor about giving Psyllium to anyone younger than 12 years.
Stop taking Psyllium and call your doctor if you have pain, swelling or bulging in your belly, rectal bleeding or have not had a bowel movement after taking.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Psyllium is a fiber-based laxative. It adds bulk and moisture to your intestine, which softens stool and makes it easier to pass.
basics.bottom_line: The natural psyllium fiber in Psyllium does more than relieve constipation. It lowers cholesterol, keeps blood sugar levels healthy, and makes you feel less hungry between meals.
downsides: You may have to take Psyllium daily for 1-3 days to see full effects.
If you don't take it with enough liquid, it could swell, block your throat and cause choking.
Not the best choice for people who have swallowing problems or aren't able to drink lots of liquids.
Psyllium contains psyllium. Don't take if you have an allergy to psyllium from breathing it in or swallowing it.
Can cause gas and mild belly cramps.

downsides_processed.orig: You may have to take Psyllium daily for 1-3 days to see full effects.
If you don't take it with enough liquid, it could swell, block your throat and cause choking.
Not the best choice for people who have swallowing problems or aren't able to drink lots of liquids.
Psyllium contains psyllium. Don't take if you have an allergy to psyllium from breathing it in or swallowing it.
Can cause gas and mild belly cramps.

upsides: Psyllium is the most recommended brand of natural fiber laxative
Some people feel that taking Psyllium is a hassle, but most think it's worth it.
It has multiple health benefits, good to control your hunger between meals, improves your blood sugar and lowers cholesterol levels.
Studies show it works better than a stool softener for constipation.

upsides_processed.orig: Psyllium is the most recommended brand of natural fiber laxative
Some people feel that taking Psyllium is a hassle, but most think it's worth it.
It has multiple health benefits, good to control your hunger between meals, improves your blood sugar and lowers cholesterol levels.
Studies show it works better than a stool softener for constipation.

risk_factors: Other condition that causes blockage or narrowing of bowel

These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reaction
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Psyllium can cause allergic reaction and life-threatening organ failure. Call your doctor and get medical care right away if you have fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Psyllium can cause allergic reaction and life-threatening organ failure. Call your doctor and get medical care right away if you have fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately.

carousel_items: Dissolve Miralax powder in 4 to 8 ounces of water, juice or other drink (cold or hot) once a day.
Works in about 1 to 3 days. Don't use for more than 1 week.
Miralax is available in four different size dose bottles. It also come in pre-measured single-dose packets to make dosing easier or if you travel.
Ask your doctor about giving it to anyone younger than 17 years.
Doesn't cause as much bloating, cramping or feelings like you "have to go right now" as other medicines to treat constipation.
Ask your doctor before you take Miralax if you have nausea or vomiting, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), kidney disease, or sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Stop using Miralax and call your doctor if you have pain, cramping, swelling or bulging in your belly, diarrhea, rectal bleeding or find you need to use for more than 1 week.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Miralax is an osmotic laxative. It uses osmosis to keep more water in your intestine, which softens your stool and makes it easier to pass.
basics.bottom_line: Miralax provides effective relief of constipation without "cramping" your style.
downsides: You have to dissolve Miralax in a beverage and drink it versus taking a pill.
It's not for children 16 years or younger.
Miralax doesn't work overnight. It can take up to 2-4 days to have a bowel movement.
It's not recommended that you take it for more than a week, so it you haven't had any success, you'll need to call your doctor for other laxative options.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to dissolve Miralax in a beverage and drink it versus taking a pill.
It's not for children 16 years or younger.
Miralax doesn't work overnight. It can take up to 2-4 days to have a bowel movement.
It's not recommended that you take it for more than a week, so it you haven't had any success, you'll need to call your doctor for other laxative options.

upsides: Miralax is the most recommended laxative by pharmacists and doctors.
Most people felt it was worth the hassle.
It's gluten and sugar free.
It causes little to no cramping, bloating, gas, or feelings like you "have to go right now" compared to some other medicines to treat constipation.
Works differently than other over-the-counter laxatives so it's a great alternative if other medicines haven't worked.

Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

risks_warnings.title: Electrolyte imbalance
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Miralax or taking it for too long can cause changes in your electrolytes. Electrolytes help your body function properly. Make sure you take Miralax as directed on the product label or by your doctor or pharmacist.
risk_factors: Taking with medications that cause electrolyte imbalance

description_processed.orig: Taking too much Miralax or taking it for too long can cause changes in your electrolytes. Electrolytes help your body function properly. Make sure you take Miralax as directed on the product label or by your doctor or pharmacist.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Using Miralax isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor about other medication choices to treat your condition.

description_processed.orig: Using Miralax isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor about other medication choices to treat your condition.

risks_warnings.title: Bowel blockage
risks_warnings.description: Stop taking Miralax and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, pain or bulging in your belly that doesn't go away, have rectal bleeding, and no bowel movement after taking. These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.
risk_factors: Other condition that causes blockage or narrowing of bowel

description_processed.orig: Stop taking Miralax and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, pain or bulging in your belly that doesn't go away, have rectal bleeding, and no bowel movement after taking. These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.

carousel_items: It's best to take it at bedtime or as your doctor has prescribed, but not for more than one week. Works in about 6-12 hours.
Ask your doctor about giving Senna to anyone younger than 2 years.
Ask your doctor before taking Senna if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Check with your baby doctor before using or if you're pregnant or breastfeeding.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Senna is a plant-derived stimulant laxative. It causes waves of contractions (peristalsis) in your intestine muscles to push stool through. It also makes stool more watery.
basics.bottom_line: Senna is gentle and effective, but it may be weaker than other laxatives.
downsides: It may be gentle, but it's not the strongest laxative for constipation.
Senna can cause cramping or the feeling that you "have to go right now".

downsides_processed.orig: It may be gentle, but it's not the strongest laxative for constipation.
Senna can cause cramping or the feeling that you "have to go right now".

upsides: Senna was used over 3,500 years ago, so it's been around for a while.
It's clinically proven to relieve constipation from a variety of causes.
One of the few laxatives that can be given to children 2 and older.
It may not work for everyone, but people felt it was worth the hassle.

upsides_processed.orig: Senna was used over 3,500 years ago, so it's been around for a while.
It's clinically proven to relieve constipation from a variety of causes.
One of the few laxatives that can be given to children 2 and older.
It may not work for everyone, but people felt it was worth the hassle.

drugs.name: Senna

carousel_items_processed.orig: It's best to take it at bedtime or as your doctor has prescribed, but not for more than one week. Works in about 6-12 hours.
Ask your doctor about giving Senna to anyone younger than 2 years.
Ask your doctor before taking Senna if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Check with your baby doctor before using or if you're pregnant or breastfeeding.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

risks_warnings.title: Bowel blockage
risks_warnings.description: Stop taking Senna and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, pain or bulging in your belly that doesn't go away, have rectal bleeding, and no bowel movement after taking. These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.
risk_factors: Other condition that causes blockage or narrowing of bowel

description_processed.orig: Stop taking Senna and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, pain or bulging in your belly that doesn't go away, have rectal bleeding, and no bowel movement after taking. These may be symptoms of a bowel blockage (bowel obstruction) which is serious.

risks_warnings.title: Laxative dependence
risks_warnings.description: don't use Senna for more than 1 week. Constipation is common in people who are on certain medications, aren't able to be active or can't move well, or don't drink enough water or other fluids. Older people are less sensitive to being thirsty, so they drink less, can get dehydrated and constipated. It’s always best to use Senna short-term. Better long term solutions may be stool softeners, bulk-forming fiber therapy, and osmotic medicines.
risk_factors: People who can't walk or move well (immobility)

description_processed.orig: don't use Senna for more than 1 week. Constipation is common in people who are on certain medications, aren't able to be active or can't move well, or don't drink enough water or other fluids. Older people are less sensitive to being thirsty, so they drink less, can get dehydrated and constipated. It’s always best to use Senna short-term. Better long term solutions may be stool softeners, bulk-forming fiber therapy, and osmotic medicines.

risks_warnings.title: Allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Senna is a natural plant-based laxative that can have a cross-allergy with aloe, which is also plant-based. People with a history of allergy to aloe may develop an allergic reaction to Senna.  Most cases are described as skin irritation that’s red and itchy, but rarely there were more serious skin reactions (e.g. erythema multiforme, toxic epidermal necrolysis).
risk_factors: Allergy or sensitivity to aloe (cross-allergic reaction)

description_processed.orig: Senna is a natural plant-based laxative that can have a cross-allergy with aloe, which is also plant-based. People with a history of allergy to aloe may develop an allergic reaction to Senna.  Most cases are described as skin irritation that’s red and itchy, but rarely there were more serious skin reactions (e.g. erythema multiforme, toxic epidermal necrolysis).

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Senna isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor first.

description_processed.orig: Senna isn't recommended during pregnancy or if you're breast-feeding. Talk to your baby doctor first.

carousel_items: Docusate/Senna is a combination of a laxative and stool softener. Together they work to relieve constipation better than each medicine alone.
Best to take at bedtime or as your doctor has prescribed, but not for more than one week. It works in about 6-12 hours.
Ask your doctor about giving Docusate/Senna to anyone younger than 2 years.
Don't use if you're taking mineral oil for constipation. Ask your doctor first.
Ask your doctor before taking Docusate/Senna if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting or had sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Check with your baby doctor before using or if you're pregnant or breastfeeding.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Docusate/Senna is a combination medicine. Docusate is a stool softener, and Senna is a stimulant laxative. These two ingredients work together to make stools easier to pass.
basics.bottom_line: Senna and docusate join forces to create Docusate/Senna, a vegetable-based laxative that gently relieves constipation.
downsides: Most people felt that it's not the most effective laxative out there, but they could deal with the hassle and it worked pretty well.
Docusate/Senna can cause cramping or the feeling that you "have to go right now".

downsides_processed.orig: Most people felt that it's not the most effective laxative out there, but they could deal with the hassle and it worked pretty well.
Docusate/Senna can cause cramping or the feeling that you "have to go right now".

upsides: The combination of a laxative and stool softener might work better for people with constipation caused by medicines.
The laxative in Docusate/Senna was used over 3,500 years ago, so it's been around for a while.
Docusate/Senna is clinically proven to relieve constipation from a variety of causes.
One of the few laxative/stool-softener combinations that can be given to children 2 and older.
It may not work for everyone, but people felt it was worth the hassle.

It may not work for everyone, but people felt it was worth the hassle.

risks_warnings.description: Docusate/Senna is a natural plant-based laxative that can have a cross-allergy with aloe, which is also plant-based. People with a history of allergy to aloe may develop an allergic reaction to Docusate/Senna.  Most cases are described as skin irritation that’s red and itchy, but rarely there were more serious skin reactions (e.g. erythema multiforme, toxic epidermal necrolysis).

description_processed.orig: Docusate/Senna is a natural plant-based laxative that can have a cross-allergy with aloe, which is also plant-based. carousel_items: Dissolve Miralax powder in 4 to 8 ounces of water, juice or other drink (cold or hot) once a day.
Works in about 1 to 3 days. Don't use for more than 1 week.
Miralax is available in four different size dose bottles. It also come in pre-measured single-dose packets to make dosing easier or if you travel.
Ask your doctor about giving it to anyone younger than 17 years.
Doesn't cause as much bloating, cramping or feelings like you "have to go right now" as other medicines to treat constipation.
Ask your doctor before you take Miralax if you have nausea or vomiting, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), kidney disease, or sudden changes in your stool for more than 2 weeks.
Stop using Miralax and call your doctor if you have pain, cramping, swelling or bulging in your belly, diarrhea, rectal bleeding or find you need to use for more than 1 week.
Talk to you doctor about eating certain foods and getting more exercise to help prevent your constipation.

basics.benefits_moa: Miralax is an osmotic laxative. It uses osmosis to keep more water in your intestine, which softens your stool and makes it easier to pass.
basics.bottom_line: Miralax provides effective relief of constipation without "cramping" your style.
downsides: You have to dissolve Miralax in a beverage and drink it versus taking a pill.
It's not for children 16 years or younger.
Miralax doesn't work overnight. It can take up to 2-4 days to have a bowel movement.
It's not recommended that you take it for more than a week, so it you haven't had any success, you'll need to call your doctor for other laxative options.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to dissolve Miralax in a beverage and drink it versus taking a pill.
It's not for children 16 years or younger.
Miralax doesn't work overnight. It can take up to 2-4 days to have a bowel movement.
It's not recommended that you take it for more than a week, so it you haven't had any success, you'll need to call your doctor for other laxative options.

upsides: Miralax is the most recommended laxative by pharmacists and doctors.
Most people felt it was worth the hassle.
It's gluten and sugar free.
It causes little to no cramping, bloating, gas, or feelings like you "have to go right now" compared to some other medicines to treat constipation.
Works differently than other over-the-counter laxatives so it's a great alternative if other medicines haven't worked.

Most people felt it was worth the hassle.
It's gluten and sugar free.
It causes little to no cramping, bloating, gas, or feelings like you "have to go right now" compared to some other medicines to treat constipation.
Works differently than other over-the-counter laxatives so it's a great alternative if other medicines haven't worked.

userStories.tip: How expensive it is over the counter vs by prescription. Get your doc to prescribe it in a big bottle if you're going to be taking it over time.
